sub_topic: Chemical reaction kinetics and rate equations
message_1: A chemical reaction follows first-order reaction kinetics with a rate constant of 0.05 min^-1. If the initial concentration of the reactant is 0.1 mol/L, what will be its concentration after 30 minutes?
message_2:
For a first-order reaction, the concentration of the reactant at any time can be calculated using the integrated rate law:

Ct = C0 * e^(-kt)

where:
Ct = concentration of the reactant at time t
C0 = initial concentration of the reactant
k = rate constant
t = time

In this case, we have:
C0 = 0.1 mol/L
k = 0.05 min^-1
t = 30 minutes

Now, we can plug these values into the integrated rate law equation:

Ct = 0.1 * e^(-0.05 * 30)

Ct = 0.1 * e^(-1.5)

Ct ≈ 0.1 * 0.2231

Ct ≈ 0.02231 mol/L

So, the concentration of the reactant after 30 minutes will be approximately 0.02231 mol/L.
